response_requirements.initial_response_description: Agency must respond within 5 business days by providing records, acknowledging receipt with reasonable time estimate, or denying request with legal basis
response_requirements.final_response_notes: If immediate response not possible, agency must provide reasonable time estimate based on nature and volume of records; must communicate regularly about status
response_requirements.extension_notes: No specific extension period; agency must provide reasonable time estimate and periodic updates

fee_structure.search_fee_notes: Actual cost of copying; staff time for locating and reviewing records if substantial; cannot charge for initial review to determine exemptions or for overhead
fee_structure.copy_fee_notes: Actual cost of copying per written fee schedule; must be reasonable and related to actual costs
fee_structure.electronic_fee: Cannot exceed cost of physical copies

exemptions.description: Personal information in government personnel files
Personal information including Social Security numbers, home addresses, phone numbers

appeal_process.first_level_notes: No formal administrative appeal for local agencies; state agencies may request Attorney General review; any person may petition superior court for injunctive or declaratory relief
appeal_process.attorney_fees_notes: Plaintiff may recover attorney fees and costs if substantially prevails; court may impose daily penalty of $5-$100 per day for each record wrongfully withheld

requester_requirements.purpose_notes: Cannot withhold records based on requester's identity; no requirement to state purpose
requester_requirements.request_format_notes: No specific format required; may be in person, by mail, or email; agencies may recommend using agency form or webpage
requester_requirements.specific_format: Must request identifiable public records; cannot be overly broad or unclear

agency_obligations.records_officer_notes: Each agency must designate Public Records Officer (PRO) as primary contact; PRO must complete mandatory PRA training within 90 days
agency_obligations.response_format_options: Must provide in format requested if readily available; electronic records have same access rights as physical; cannot charge more for electronic than physical copies
agency_obligations.liberal_construction: Liberally construed to promote public access; exemptions narrowly construed
agency_obligations.training_notes: PROs and governing body members must complete mandatory PRA training within 90 days; refresher training required every four years

oversight_body.name: Washington State Attorney General
oversight_body.role: Maintains Model Rules (WAC 44-14) for PRA compliance; provides training; reviews state agency denials upon request

primary_sources: Washington Public Records Act statutory text
validation_metadata.verification_notes: All fields verified from official Washington statute. Response timeline: 5 business days to respond (provide records, acknowledge with time estimate, or deny); no specific extension period but must provide reasonable time estimates. Over 500 exemptions throughout Washington statutes. Mandatory Public Records Officer designation with training requirement (90 days, refresher every 4 years). Strong enforcement with attorney fees and daily penalties ($5-$100 per day per record). Liberal construction favoring disclosure. Attorney General maintains Model Rules and provides training. Cannot withhold based on requester identity. Electronic records have same access rights as physical. Replaced 1972 Public Disclosure Act in 2006.
